178.title: Arbital "tag" relationship
178.clickbait: Tags are a way to connect pages that share a common topic.

370.editSummary: reflecting the fact that we only have one type of mark now.
370.title: Arbital mark
370.clickbait: What is a mark on Arbital? When is it created? Why is it important?

561.title: Odds: Introduction
561.clickbait: What's the difference between probabilities and odds? Why is a 20% probability of success equivalent to 1 : 4 odds favoring success?

565.title: Conditional probability: Refresher
565.clickbait: Is P(yellow | banana) the probability that a banana is yellow, or the probability that a yellow thing is a banana?

597.title: Arbital page clickbait
597.clickbait: The text you are reading right now is clickbait.

17b.title: Arbital lens
17b.clickbait: A lens is a page that presents another page's content from a different angle.

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1lw.title: Mathematics
1lw.clickbait: Mathematics is the study of numbers and other ideal objects that can be described by axioms.

1lx.title: Ability to read algebra
1lx.clickbait: Do you have sufficient mathematical ability that you can read a sentence that uses some algebra or invokes a mathematical idea, without slowing down too much?

1ly.title: Bayesian update
1ly.clickbait: Bayesian updating: the ideal way to change probabilistic beliefs based on evidence.

1lz.title: Bayes' rule
1lz.clickbait: Bayes' rule is the core theorem of probability theory saying how to revise our beliefs when we make a new observation.

1r5.title: Math 1
1r5.clickbait: Is math sometimes fun for you, and are you not anxious if you see a math puzzle you don't know how to solve?

1r6.title: Math 2
1r6.clickbait: Do you work with math on a fairly routine basis?  Do you have little trouble grasping abstract structures and ideas?

1rd.title: Mutually exclusive and exhaustive
1rd.clickbait: The condition needed for probabilities to sum to 1

1rf.title: Probability
1rf.clickbait: The degree to which someone believes something, measured on a scale from 0 to 1, allowing us to do math to it.

1rj.title: Conditional probability
1rj.clickbait: The notation for writing "The probability that someone has green eyes, if we know that they have red hair."

1rk.title: Normalization (probability)
1rk.clickbait: That thingy we do to make sure our probabilities sum to 1, when they should sum to 1.

1rm.title: Prior probability
1rm.clickbait: What we believed before seeing the evidence.

1rp.title: Posterior probability
1rp.clickbait: What we believe, after seeing the evidence and doing a Bayesian update.

1rq.title: Relative likelihood
1rq.clickbait: How relatively likely an observation is, given two or more hypotheses, determines the strength and direction of evidence.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

1wy.title: Waterfall diagram
1wy.clickbait: Visualizing Bayes' rule as the mixing of probability streams.

1x1.title: Waterfall diagrams and relative odds
1x1.clickbait: A way to visualize Bayes' rule that yields an easier way to solve some problems

1x5.title: Bayes' rule: Odds form
1x5.clickbait: The simplest and most easily understandable form of Bayes' rule uses relative odds.

1x8.title: Introduction to Bayes' rule: Odds form
1x8.clickbait: Bayes' rule is simple, if you think in terms of relative odds.
1x8.text:
[summary: The odds form of Bayes' rule is a form of [1lz Bayes' rule] that uses [1rq relative likelihoods] and [-1rb]. It says that in general, the [1rm prior] odds times the [56t likelihood ratio] equals the [1rp posterior] odds.

[22s Suppose] that the odds of a particular patient being sick are about $(1 : 4),$ i.e., they may be drawn from a population where there is 1 sick patient for every 4 healthy ones. Suppose we administer a test which comes back positive 90% of the time if the patient is _actually_ sick, but also comes back positive 30% of the time even when the patient is healthy; this means relative likelihoods of $(90 : 30) = (3 : 1)$: the test is 3x as likely to come back positive if the patient is sick. Bayes' rule then says that the odds of the patient being sick _after_ observing a positive test are $(1 : 4) \times (3 : 1) = (3 : 4),$ for a final probability of about $3/(3+4) \approx 43\%.$]

%%!if-after([1x1]):
**This introduction is meant to be read after the introductions to [55z frequency visualizations] and [1x1 waterfall visualizations].**
%%

In general, Bayes' rule states:

$$ \textbf{Prior odds} \times \textbf{Relative likelihoods} = \textbf{Posterior odds}$$

If we consider the [1wy waterfall visualization] of [22s the Diseasitis example], 
then we can visualize how *relative odds* are appropriate for thinking about the two rivers at the top of the waterfall. 

![Waterfall visualization](https://i.imgur.com/eQh2qUt.png?0)

The *proportion* of red vs. blue water at the bottom will be the same whether there's 200 vs. 800 gallons per second of red vs. blue water at the top of the waterfall, or 20,000 vs. 80,000 gallons/sec, or 1 vs. 4 gallons/second.  So long as the rest of the waterfall behaves in a proportional way, we'll get the same proportion of red vs blue at the bottom. Thus, we're justified in ignoring the _amount_ of water and considering only the relative proportion between amounts.

Similarly, what matters is the *relative* proportion between how much of each gallon of red water makes it into the shared pool, and how much of each gallon of blue water, makes it.  45% and 15% of the red and blue water making it to the bottom would give the same *relative proportion* of red and blue water in the bottom pool as 90% and 30%.

![Changing the proportion makes no difference](https://i.imgur.com/6FOndjc.png?0)

This justifies throwing away the specific data that 90% of the red stream and 30% of the blue stream make it down, and summarizing this into *relative likelihoods* of (3 : 1).

More generally, suppose we have a medical test that detects a sickness with a 90% true positive rate (10% false negatives) and a 30% false positive rate (70% true negatives).  A positive result on this test represents the same *strength of evidence* as a test with 60% true positives and 20% false positives.  A negative result on this test represents the same *strength of evidence* as a test with 9% false negatives and 63% true negatives.

In general, the strength of evidence is summarized by how *relatively* likely different states of the world make our observations. %%!if-before([1zh]): For more on this idea, see  [22x]. %% %%if-before([1zh]): More on this later. %%

# The equation

To state Bayes' rule in full generality, and prove it as a theorem, we'll need to introduce some new notation.

## Conditional probability

First, when $X$ is a proposition, $\mathbb P(X)$ will stand for the [1rf probability] of $X.$

In other words, $X$ is something that's either true or false in reality, but we're uncertain about it, and $\mathbb P(X)$ is a way of expressing our [4y9 degree of belief] that $X$ is true.  A patient is, in fact, either sick or healthy; but if you don't know which of these is the case, the evidence might lead you to assign a 43% subjective probability that the patient is sick.

$\mathbb \neg X$ will mean "$X$ is false", so $\mathbb P(\neg X)$ is the "the probability $X$ is false".

The Diseasitis involved some more complicated statements than this, though; in particular it involved:

- The 90% chance that a patient blackens the tongue depressor, *given* that they have Diseasitis.
- The 30% chance that a patient blackens the tongue depressor, *given* that they're healthy.
- The 3/7 chance that a patient has Diseasitis, *given* that they blackened the tongue depressor.

In these cases we want to go from some fact that is *assumed* or *known* to be true (on the right), to some other proposition (on the left) whose new probability we want to ask about, taking into account that assumption.

Probability statements like those are known as "conditional probabilities".  The standard notation for conditional probability expresses the above quantities as:

- $\mathbb P(blackened \mid sick) = 0.9$
- $\mathbb P(blackened \mid \neg sick) = 0.3$
- $\mathbb P(sick \mid blackened) = 3/7$

This standard notation for $\mathbb P(X \mid Y)$ meaning "the probability of $X$, assuming $Y$ to be true" is a helpfully symmetrical vertical line, to avoid giving you any visual clue to remember that the assumption is on the right and the inferred proposition is on the left. </sarcasm>

Conditional probability is *defined* as follows:

$$\mathbb P(X \mid Y) := \frac{\mathbb P(X \text{ and } Y)}{\mathbb P(Y)}$$

%todo: introduce \wedge here, since used below%

E.g. in the Diseasitis example, $\mathbb P(sick \mid  blackened)$ is calculated by dividing the 18 students who are sick *and* have blackened tongue depressors, by the total 42 students who have blackened tongue depressors.

Or $\mathbb P(blackened \mid \neg sick),$ the probability of blackening the tongue depressor *given* that you're healthy, is equivalent to the 24 students who are healthy *and* have blackened tongue depressors, divided by the 80 students who are healthy.  24 / 80 = 3/10, so this corresponds to the 30% false positives we were told about at the start.

We can see the law of conditional probability as saying, "Let us restrict our attention to worlds where $Y$ is the case, or thingies of which $Y$ is true.  Looking only at cases where $Y$ is true, how many cases are there *inside* that restriction where $X$ is *also* true - cases with $X$ *and* $Y$?"

For more on this, see [1rj].

## Bayes' rule

Bayes' rule says:

$$\textbf{Prior odds} \times \textbf{Relative likelihoods} = \textbf{Posterior odds}$$

In the Diseasitis example, this would state:

$$\dfrac{\mathbb P({sick})}{\mathbb P(healthy)} \times \dfrac{\mathbb P({blackened}\mid {sick})}{\mathbb P({blackened}\mid healthy)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P({sick}\mid {blackened})}{\mathbb P(healthy\mid {blackened})}.$$

The [1rm prior] odds refer to the relative proportion of sick vs healthy patients, which is $1 : 4$. Converting these odds into probabilities gives us $\mathbb P(sick)=\frac{1}{4+1}=\frac{1}{5}=20\%$.

The [-1rq] refers to how much more likely each sick patient is to get a positive test result than each healthy patient, which (using [1rj conditional probability notation]) is $\frac{\mathbb P(positive \mid sick)}{\mathbb P(positive \mid healthy)}=\frac{90}{30},$ aka relative likelihoods of $3 : 1.$

The [1rp posterior] odds are the relative proportions of sick vs healthy patients among those with positive test results, or $\frac{\mathbb P(sick \mid positive)}{\mathbb P(healthy \mid positive)} = \frac{3}{4}$, aka $3 : 4$ odds.

Using the waterfall visualization:

![labeled waterfall](https://i.imgur.com/CXsoZhA.png?0)

We can generalize this to _any_ two **hypotheses** $H_j$ and $H_k$ with **evidence** $e$, in which case Bayes' rule can be written as:

$$\dfrac{\mathbb P(H_j)}{\mathbb P(H_k)} \times \dfrac{\mathbb P(e \mid H_j)}{\mathbb P(e \mid H_k)} = \dfrac{\mathbb P(H_j \mid e)}{\mathbb P(H_k \mid e)}, \tag{1}$$

which says "the posterior odds ratio for hypotheses $H_j$ vs $H_k$ (after seeing the evidence $e$) are equal to the prior odds ratio times the ratio of how well $H_j$ predicted the evidence compared to $H_k.$"

If $H_j$ and $H_k$ are [-1rd], we can convert the posterior odds into a posterior probability for $H_j$ by [1rk normalizing] the odds - dividing through the odds ratio by the sum of its terms, so that the elements of the new ratio sum to $1.$  If the odds are currently expressed as $(3 : 4)$ for "sick" versus "not sick", and everyone is either sick or not sick, we divide through by 3+4 to get $(\frac{3}{3 + 4} : \frac{4}{3+4})$ in which the elements of the ratio sum to $1$, and these are the probabilities $(0.43 : 0.57).$

%todo: move discussion of normalization closer to the waterfall that shows it%

## Proof of Bayes' rule

Rearranging [1rj the definition of conditional probability], $\mathbb P(X \wedge Y) = \mathbb P(Y) \cdot \mathbb P(X|Y).$  E.g. to find "the fraction of all patients that are sick *and* get a positive result", we multiply "the fraction of patients that are sick" times "the probability that a sick patient blackens the tongue depressor".

Then this is a proof of Bayes' rule:

$$
\frac{\mathbb P(H_j)}{\mathbb P(H_k)}
\cdot
\frac{\mathbb P(e_0 | H_j)}{\mathbb P(e_0 | H_k)}
=
\frac{\mathbb P(e_0 \wedge H_j)}{\mathbb P(e_0 \wedge H_k)}
= 
\frac{\mathbb P(H_j \wedge e_0)/\mathbb P(e_0)}{\mathbb P(H_k \wedge e_0)/\mathbb P(e_0)}
= 
\frac{\mathbb P(H_j | e_0)}{\mathbb P(H_k | e_0)}
$$

QED.

In the Diseasitis example, these proof steps correspond to the operations:

$$
\frac{0.80}{0.20}
\cdot
\frac{0.90}{0.30}
=
\frac{0.18}{0.24}
= 
\frac{0.18/0.42}{0.24/0.42}
= 
\frac{0.43}{0.57}
$$

Using red for sick, blue for healthy, grey for a mix of sick and healthy patients, and + signs for positive test results, the calculation steps can be visualized as follows:

![bayes venn](https://i.imgur.com/YBc2nYo.png?0)

This process of observing evidence and using its likelihood ratio to transform a prior belief into a posterior belief is called a "[1ly Bayesian update]" or "belief revision."

%%!if-before([1zg]):
- For the generalization of the odds form of Bayes' rule to multiple hypotheses and multiple items of evidence, see [1zg].
- For a transformation of the odds form that makes the strength of evidence even more directly visible, see [1zh].
%%

1xr.title: Proof of Bayes' rule
1xr.clickbait: Proofs of Bayes' rule, with graphics

1y9.title: Probability notation for Bayes' rule
1y9.clickbait: The probability notation used in Bayesian reasoning

1zg.title: Bayes' rule: Vector form
1zg.clickbait: For when you want to apply Bayes' rule to lots of evidence and lots of variables, all in one go. (This is more or less how spam filters work.)

1zh.title: Bayes' rule: Log-odds form
1zh.clickbait: A simple transformation of Bayes' rule reveals tools for measuring degree of belief, and strength of evidence.

21v.title: Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence
21v.clickbait: The people who adamantly claim they were abducted by aliens do provide some evidence for aliens. They just don't provide quantitatively enough evidence.

22s.title: Diseasitis
22s.clickbait: 20% of patients have Diseasitis. 90% of sick patients and 30% of healthy patients turn a tongue depressor black. You turn a tongue depressor black. What's the chance you have Diseasitis?

22x.title: Strength of Bayesian evidence
22x.clickbait: From a Bayesian standpoint, the strength of evidence can be identified with its likelihood ratio.

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

4y9.title: Interpretations of "probability"
4y9.clickbait: What does it *mean* to say that a fair coin has a 50% probability of coming up heads?
